text: Solid black lager, sufficiently dark and roasty, adding a yummy charred malt complexity to its lager fruitiness. Pours a lovely deep brown with ample lace, and the aroma hits a welcome smoky mocha note. Tastes rather stout-like at first, with a massive amount of roasted chocolate blending with an apple and apricot-tinted yeasty backbone, yet it remains surprisingly light for a beer with this much dark malt character. Finishes like semisweet coffee with a breadlike undercurrent. Nice.
650ml bottle. Black with a heap of brown foam. Roasty, earthy, BBQ, espresso, dark chocolate and hoppy aroma. Similar kind of taste, quite bitter, chewy texture. Very nice.
Pours a brownish-black color. Aroma of chocolate/coffee as well as a hint of nuts? Flavor of coffee, bittersweet chocolate and bit of caramel.

650ml bottle poured thick black & frothy not dissimilar to a half decent stout though tastes & smells nothing like a stout or a lager flavours are malty rich chocolate sugary sweet havent overly enjoyed previous Schwarzbiers & considering the rating of this was expecting more ok but not really my thing

Pours a jet black with a thick black head. Aroma is chocolate, roast, earthy hops, and some odd fruity notes. Flavor is very similar, with a sweetness that slightly outweighs the bitterness. Very good, though the fruitiness throws things off for me.

From the 650 ml. bottle. Jet black pour with lingering tan to light brown head. Big charred, burnt malt character on the nose. Smooth medium to full body. The same burnt roasted malt character is in the flavor at first but there is also an odd buttery character too, which was a tad disappointing.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

Presumably some years on the bottle but I cannot find any date so Black solid mocha; Nose is lightly metallic soy sauce, umami malts with light mocha. Taste is lightly metallic, soy, surprisingly thick & substantial chocolate body, light charcoal, coffee, dark chocolate. Body feels a bit thinned out but still very substantial. Lovely Schwarzbier. Ingredients mention Free Range Costal Water (seriously, free range water,. Hahaha).

Muito boa. Um pouco ácida mas equilibra com o amargor e o saber torrado de malte. Surpreendeu o creme muito alto e muuuuito persistente.

Linda cerveja negra, espuma marrom em média quantidade, cremosa, bom lacing, pequenas bolhas irregulares por toda a superfície. Logo ao servir já é possível notar o aroma licoroso, achocolatado, adocicado, em menor quantidade café, cacau; amargor perceptível mas menos intenso, palha seca. Com o aumento da temperatura exalou um odor que lembra xarope, e o chocolate ficou mais intenso. Corpo leve/médio, carbonação média. Paladar bastante equilibrado/prazeiroso, com aftertaste amargo de grãos torrados. Uma boa SchwarzBeer.
Dark beer. Thick creamy head. Flavours of chocolate, coffee, cedar and smoke. Very smooth and easy drinking.

22 oz bottle shared by Tmoney99 years ago from notes. Pours a dark cola brown color with a small tan head. The aroma had roasted malts, coffee, earthy hops, and some orange citrus in the background. The flavor had earthy and citrusy hops, roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate. Medium bodied with good flavor; one of the better beers Ive had from Rogue in a while although I probably wouldnt revisit this.
On draft. Rich black with thick tan head and strong lacing. Medium body with roasty coffee bean palate. Not sweet, not sour, a little bitter on the finish, from the coffee. Decent.

650 ml bottle served in a pint glass (from notes). 

Pour looks a bit like used motor oil; this is a truly black beer. Completely opaque with an unusually dark brown head that reduces at a moderate rate to a thin ring. 

Aroma: Not strong. Primary component is dark roasted malt. Very sweet, with lots of chocolate/smoky notes. Toasted malt and burnt toast, powdery cocoa, hints of coffee, and molasses. 

T - Some sweetness initially, but certainly not as sweet as a typical German schwarzbier, and the finish is mildly bitter with a clear coffee note. Hints of dark chocolate and licorice. Mainly, theres plenty of rich dark roasted malt flavor that is pronounced and lasting but not challenging. 

M - nice medium-full body with some crispness from carbonation and/or hops. 

O - recommended for fans of schwarzbier who also like an imperial stout: This schwarzbier heads in that direction.

Keg at CASC. Black body with a beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma of ham, chocolate and roasted malt. Flavour of chocolate and straw. Thin body with a smooth texture. Soft fizz. Decent. Tastes like a light Porter.
660ml bottle from mchughs. Pours jet oily black. Coffee lactose chocolate nose. Flavour is sweet roast malts. Dry short finish with a fizzy lift. A bit light but nice.

Julie loves a tinge of smoke up front pretty good aroma.  V.  Julie gives a 3.5

Taste is coffee, ash, liquorice, slightly metallic. Im not a massive fan of liquorice, and this affects my rating. Drinkable but not moreish.

Poured from tap to glass at the farm in Independence. Dark hue with tan head. Aroma is malt, sulphur, roast, floral. Mouthfeel is nice with a medium light body and crisp carbonation. Taste is dry throughout with a bitterness in the following and a clean finish. Overall this is an enjoyable brew.

Reviewed from notes. 
This was poured into a pilsener glass. 
The appearance was a jet black pour and color. One finger white to off white foamy head graces the top of the beer in a gentle way. As the head dissipated, semi - thick foamy lacing strings its way down the sides of the glass. 
The smell was roasty and sweet with a nice coffee bean to chocolate sweetness. A light bitter edge of coffee to touch the aroma pretty nicely. 
The taste was sweet, roasty and a light bitter from the coffee edge. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat sharp but too much. There was a nice roasty to sweet sharp aftertaste and finish. 
Overall, good Schwarzbier Id have again.

Transfer from BA review on 1-30-13-
 Served on tap in a pint glass

 Appearance  Served a black colored brew with a tiny tan head. The head fades almost instantly leaving a light level of lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell- The aroma is strongest of a roasted coffee aroma. Mixed with this is a nice dark chocolate/cocoa smell. A light sweet vanilla and caramel smell are mixed with these roasted and dark aromas balancing them nicely and creating a great smell.

 Taste  The taste begins with some slightly sweeter chocolate and roasted malt notes up front. As the flavors advance further a bit of caramel and some smoky and coffee flavors come to the tongue. These flavors last to the end of the taste where the coffee flavors get stronger and espresso like with the brew also bittering more in nature. These are accompanied by an emergence of some earthy hop flavors. When mixed with the bitter coffee, and roasted malts it creates a very pleasing slightly bitter flavor to linger on the tongue. 

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the thicker and chewier side with a carbonation level that is on the average side. The chewier body is fantastic for the roasted and darker flavors of the beer giving is a big and thick feel on the tongue; well matching the coffee and chocolate flavors of the brew.

 Overall- This was one tasty brew. It had the right level of bitter hop and sweetness to complement the darker and roastier chocolate and coffee/espresso flavors of the brew. Well done.
Dark lager, schwarzbier at its finest...dirty taster. So black and bold for the style. Drinks like a stout...smells like roasted coffee, delicious.
Dark black with a tan head. Aroma contains some chocolate, licorice, and nutty elements. Flavor is somewhat dry with some dark chocolate and coffee. Good mouthfeel on this one. Overall viva rogue.

A deep deep dark lager with a thick frothy dark brown head. In aroma, interesting mix of soy sauce, chocolate malt, caramel, quite nice. In mouth, a nice sweetish chocolate with peated notes, coffee grind, lightly smoked, quite nice. Bomber.
On tap at La Cerveteca, Barcelona. Pours black with brown head. Roasted malts, chocolate, bit hoppy and smokey.

Deepest blackest beer Ive had to date.
Pours thick like an imperial stout with a deep brown foam cap, dense and long lasting.
Smells nicely of complex rich malts, toffee and maybe pumpkin spice. Hops provide just enough earthiness and woodiness.
Very nice tasting with of course a complex malt base. Hints of chocolate and espresso.
Hops provide a nice earthy flavor but are not promident.
A very nice beer thats smooth and full bodied.
A roasted dry bitter ending that lingers in the back of the mouth for a while.
I think this would be a good beer to cellar for a while to see how it would mellow out.
This is a rich and complex tasting beer good for one or two at a time to savor.

Very black bodied and huge deep brown head, impressive looks. Smokey, roasted, dry, rye, oat, moderate hops. Drinkable, great body. But overdone malt bill for a Swartz but then again its an American dark lager. Could have been a bit simpler for a biter effect zit interesting mix of the low fermentation and American dark ale interpretation. (65cl bottle shared with Darren, from Saveur Bière)

From 22oz bottle to lager glass. Pour is a jet black color with a thick tan head. Nose is roasted malt, smoke, resin, light hop. Taste is medium bodied with a sweeter front and bitter finish. Finishes kind of dry on the back end. Good beer, but I think the finish kind of robs it of a more full bodied complexity. However very enjoyable

The taste is bitter, roasty, coffee, pepper, toast, mild acidity, tar and light soy sauce with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Not bad, Im just not a big fan of the soy sauce character kicking about.

Bottle. Pours black with a short brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Flavor of dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, a bit of caramel and had some notes of smoke with a dry and bitter finish.

Black pour with a brown head that reminded me of bubbling toffee. Roasty, malty, coffee and chocolate aromas, flavours are dark chocolate, almost sweet chocolatey liqueur. Weirdly interesting and bloody tasty

Black colour with a tan head, aroma and taste of grains and bitter dark chocolate.

2/13/2010 - Power to the beer, and power to the drinker. I love Rogues hard left socialist labeling here, but Im also eager to try my first American made schwarzbier. My European first was a palate expanding experience, and I thought an American take would be similar. As the Schwarz in the style suggests, this is a very black beer, with a deep, dark chocolate shaving colored head, putting up a centimeter and a half of insulation - a feeble attempt to protect it from a thirsty beer rater. The aroma is primarily chocolate, but mild in sweetness. It also feels wet, and has a smell not unlike moss on a damp rock. Theres also a chalky thickness to it, but rich; the Chatoe Rogue First Growth Dirtoir is neither too sweet nor bitter in the nose. This changes in the flavor, where the bitter flavors are amped up, and where the brewers heaved in a LOT of chocolate flavor. The end features some of the beginnings bitterness, but restrains it once the beer has passed to a better place (my gut.) In its place is a lingering, unctuous chocolatey flavor, reverberating for half a minute before it finally shakes itself away. The palate is lighter than I expected considering the dark flavors, but I chalk this up to conditioning. Schwarzbiers tend to be lighter, and like Black IPAs, are novel in some ways for the kinds of flavor they deliver on a lighter palate. Its a straightforward beer, but I like it. It lets me have it all - deep, dark and sinfully sweet flavors on a clean, refreshing palate.

Bottle, shared by emacgee.  Thanks!  Ive been looking forward to trying this ever since I read TARs review.  Cause Jeff knows good beer.   And hes a nice fella.  The beer is  Blacker than black with a steady tan head and lace.  Nose shows a lot of roasted malt balanced nicely with some sweeter caramel malts, some light cocoa and coffee notes. SCHIUMA:
schiuma marrone marcato, media presenza, non finissima, buona durata
COLORE:
nero impenetrabile, pulita
INTENSITA / FINEZZA / AROMA
non intensissima, con profumi di malto torrefatto, bruciato ma non affumicato, qualche nota di contorno che ricordano il caffè, la liquirizia. Luppoli quasi assenti.
GUSTO / RETROGUSTO / PERSISTENZA
entra secca , con da subito sapori amarognoli dovuti al tostato e torrefatto. Si riconosce caffè, con leggeri riflessi di liquirizia.  Lamaro tende ad essere più marcato sul finire dove dentrano in gioco anche i luppoli, anche se meno del previsto.

CORPO / CARBONATAZIONE / CONSISTENZA
corpo medio,  però con una consistenza quasi oleosa al versare nel bicchiere. Ben carbonata.

Buona, non ce che dire. Al versarla nel bicchiere uno pensa subito ad una imperial stout o baltic porter ( che si siano sbagliati a scrivere in etichetta "lager" ?!), visto il colore di birra e schiuma e la consistenza visiva molto "solida". Poi in bocca si ritorna al mondo lager, senza quel classico apporto ale leggermente astringente, le note di caffe e liquirizia e cioccolato sono molto meno evidenti, lasciando spazio ad un torrefatto spinto, secco. Lamaro rimane contenuto, i luppoli non sono dominanti ma fanno da sostegno ai malti. Per concludere, una schwarzbier complessa, sostanziosa  e molto godibile.

Im absolutely shocked right now to find a good Rogue beer... pours a nice black body with a really nice head, a solid ring forms, a solid cap as well, almost like an island surrounded by a moat... nose and taste are both just really wonderful roast with a hint of chocolate, super crushable... Id happily have this again

Bottle: pours a beautiful black, a dark brown head that fades after a minute to a pure tan color. Coffee is the overwhelming smell, but once I tasted it, i see its well balanced by a malty sweetness and lively carbonation... Great beer.

Wow, this is a pretty amazing brew. 
Looks and pours like a thick brewed coffee left on the campfire. Foamy head the color of Cocoa-Pebbles. A well-forward aroma of brownies, smoke and sweet roasted malts, maybe a hint of prunes or bananna?
Complex but pleasant.
The tastes are smooth and malty, just the right amount of smoke bite. For all the hops listed on the label, I was expecting the hops to be a bit more noticeable, but it is very well intertwined in the flavors. The finish and wash is long, well into the next swallow. Hangs around, but thats ok....I cant get enough of this brew.
One of the.....no, I think the best  brews I have rated in quite awhile.
Treat yourself to something different.....this isnt just a beer, its a brewers passion in a bottle!

Big roasted malts and a bit of bitter coffee. Big roasted flavors but a bit too much malt.
Low bitterness, roasty coffee and some char.  Mild sweetness, a bit of cocoa and some slight piney hops?  A good and drinkable beer, albeit on the thick side.

Black pour with medium tan head. A nice strong aroma of chocolate, roast and coffee.

A big dark roast flavor with a mild dry hop / chocolate finish. A big bold body.
Best black lager ever.  Looks and tastes like coffee stout but smoother and lighter.  Drink all day every day.

Pours almost black, with a dark tan head. Aroma is malty and dark, with hints of chocolate. Taste is rich and malty, with hops, chocolate, and coffee. Nice hoppy background. Smooth, well blended, and quite drinkable. Thumbs way up!

Bomber, pretty fresh.  True to its name, the body is pretty much a dense, pitch black shade.  The head is initially thick and spongy, but collapses at a moderate pace to a thin, mocha colored layer with a ring at the edge.  Scant, skinny flares of lacing jut outward from the body, barely clinging to the glass.  The nose is distinctly lagerish, clearly showing bready German yeast tendencies beneath notes of darkly roasted, almost charred black patent malt, bittersweet cocoa, bakers chocolate, and faint licorice.  Coffee roast and earthen hops join the fold, perpetuating the generally bitter theme.  Flavors largely follow suit, biting aggressively into the tongue with robust, darkly roasted, nearly burnt coffee and cocoa malts.  Earth, toasted pumpernickel crust, and scorched molasses lend further sharp richness, while crackery baking yeast lightens things up a bit.  The palate is substantive and rather chalky, drinking with considerably more heft than its 5% ABV would suggest.  Carbonation is light but persistent, working with the yeast to effectively dry out what little sugars lie within.  Those sugars do leave a sticky substance behind, though.  Pretty decent brew.  Be prepared for a roast bomb, though.

Black, with a medium, rocky brown head. Rich aroma of chocolate and roasted malts, coffee, cookies and earth. The taste is nutty and a little sweet, with some chocolate and coffee bitterness that has a very slight dryness. Body is medium and velvety smooth with moderate carbonation. Very easy drinking and nicely balanced. An excellent schwarz.

You guessed it - the beer poured a dark and solid black. The head was a few fingers thick and brown - similar to chocolate milk though not as smooth. Head retention was impressively long and ample lacing was deposited in icicles around the glass.

The aroma is of roasted malts up front with a sweetness in the finish. There are notes of chocolate, coffee and molasses in the nose.

The taste elaborates on the the aroma with a good and strong dark roasted malt flavor with some hints of burnt - but not in a bad way. This would be from the black malts which are used as coloring more than strictly flavor. In the middle of the taste you get some coffee, chocolate, and molasses as well. The beer finishes bitter with a wave of hops that balances the beer out beautifully and clears your palate for the next sip. There is a lingering finish that seems to be split between the bitter hops and roasted malts. 

Dirtoir is medium to full bodied and the carbonation is moderate. It drinks very smooth and doesnt taste like an ABV of 6.2%. 

I was extremely impressed with this beer because it delivered on the flavors I love in dark beer but kept the overall impression "light". This was not a "meal in a glass" as some would say but a light and refreshing black beer.

This has put schwarzbier on the map for me - in a big way.

Opaque black. RIch mocha froth adorns the glass and exhibits superior retention. Stellar nose of scorched malt, wafer cookies, toffee, black licorice, coffee grounds, and a big whiff of minerals. Background notes of smoke, plum skin, deeply toasted biscuits and unsweetened dark chocolate. Soft, fine carbonation. An airy, snappily mineralic, and bracingly roasty onset is shadowed by a captivating burnt wood and ashen malt surge. Expertly extracted malt boasts immensely deep notes of toffee-drizzled nuts and dabs of toasted straw which beautify the sturdy char frame. An array of nuance and soft, dusty textures exude throughout. Further enriching the char is a lush palate-clasping pillar of bitter cocoa and tar-bathed espresso beans. Beneath the complex maltiness lurks absolutely dazzling interplay of unripe plums and black-malt acidity. The body is awash with minerals which latch onto the gritty char, cleansing the palate along the way and imparting obligatory lager zip. Finishes briskly yet with softening shades of smoke and bittersweet  chocolate. The steep $7 price tag is unfortunate, IMHO, as world-class lagers need to reach a broader audience. But kudos to Rogue for crafting what surely is one of the nicest lagers this nation has ever seen. Masterful.

text: On draft at Holy Grale. Pours black, with thin, tan head. Aroma strongly of roasted malts, with clear notes of coffee and toffee. Bomber. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

APPEARANCE: Pours pitch black. Opaque. Dark tan, creamy coffee colored head is about 2-3 fingers, frothy, and with lengthy retention. A bit of lacing is left for some time as head begins to settle. 

AROMA: Huge roast aroma. Plenty of coffee. Some earthiness. Faint hops aroma, which seems herbal. 

TASTE: Earthy/dirt characteristics much more evident in taste than aroma. The earthy/dirt taste is quite pleasant. Some light citrusy hops without much hop bitterness on front of palate; behind roast and coffee. Roasted malts mid palate. Back of palate and finish is characterized by dirt and some roasted malt sweetness. 

MOUTH FEEL: Velvety, yet crisp  an outstanding combination. 

OVERALL: A remarkably smooth and quaffable black lager that is true to its name in the sense that a pleasant earthy/dirt/terroir taste is evident.

Brown bottle, 650 ml, purchased at Bangor Wine and Cheese on August 17 2010, savoured on August 24 2010; eye: black, opaque, nice dark beige head that turns into a tiny ring, no lacing; nose: roasted malt, molasses, vanilla, light caramel; mouth: roasted malt, molasses, light burnt malt, slight caramel, dry finale in roasted malt with presence of burnt malt, medium body, slightly sweet, a bit thin, lightly acidic, lightly lactic; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 650 ml, achetée chez Bangor Wine and Cheese le 17 août 2010, savourée le 24 août 2010; il : noire, opaque, belle mousse beige foncée qui se transforme en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, mélasse, vanille, léger caramel; bouche : malt torréfié, mélasse, léger malt brûlé, très léger caramel, finale sèche en malt torréfié avec présence de malt brûlé, corps moyen, très légèrement sucrée, un peu mince, légèrement acide, légèrement lactique; en résumé : bien

In short: A very roasted black beer with a strong coffee character.  Straightforward but good
How: Bottles, 22oz.  A few times.  This rating for a bottle (or two) consumed fresh a few months ago soon after the beer release.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.
The look: Black body topped by a tan ring of foam
In long: Nose is highly roasted with roasted coffee beans notes.  Taste is more of the same.  This is just a simple beer with plenty of highly roasted (almost burnt) dark malts that brings a good roasted coffee beans flavor.  A very light cacao powder sensation, a tiny bit of acidity.  As it is the case with most highly roasted beers, this one feels rather dry and not much sweetness it feels quite dry.  I would have never guessed that this is a lager/ Schwarzbier.  But the question remains.  What is a Dirtoir?  I googled it and found nothing.  Is it even a word?  It probably doesnt exist.  Maybe it is a building where we teach young chickens to dance ballet, since that probably does not exist either.
Jet black with the most intensely coloured head I have ever seen - much like espresso crema... Notes of burnt toffee, coffee, licorice and a hint of leather. Crisp weight but full in the mouth.

Bomber shared with Brenn79. Thanks Brenn! Aroma is chocolate milk and bread; I smell raisin toast. Pours black as black with a deep thick dark tan head and creamy lace. Nice smoky roasted coffee flavor. Taste is sweet, bitter, then sour in the finish. Carbonation is medium; body is full. Nice big schwarz here.

22 oz. bottle- Shared with Poisoneddwarf- Pours black with a thick tan head, lacework is outstanding, just a perfect looking beer. The aroma is porteresque, robust, cocoa. The flavor is  smoky and full flavored, personally I have a hard time saying anything bad to say about this close to perfect brew. If there was a little less bitterness or harshness it would be excellent, maybe some aging would mellow out the flavors, but there is no complaining about this, great beer.

Pours black with a chocolate colored head. Aroma is of yeast, and roasted malts... not much else going on. Taste is pretty mellow with a slight hoppy bitterness and heavy yeast flavor. Overall its a decent black lager, but nothing amazing.
Really big pop in dark roastedness to this brew. Pours deep deep brown. A bit thick but clear in the glass. Really good flavor, packed full of hops. Really nice brew, strong yet refreshing!

Multiple bottles bought on the cheap at the Rogue garage sale in Eugene. Motor oil black pour with a thin tan head that was not long for this world. Smelled of earthen hops, chocolate, molasses and raisins. Tastes of chocolate, earthen hops, light smoke and molasses. I do enjoy a tasty black lager, and this is an excellent representative of the style.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a great dark mahogany color with a thin deep tan head.  Flavors are very reminiscent of a nice imperial stout, but there is a lightness to the palate which is actually really nice.  Love the clever labeling on this as well, even though that doesnt really matter in the grand scheme of beer tasting!

Pours very black, so black it looks like a stout.  This is the first beer I have poured that had a reddish color head.  Nice easy coffee & cream aroma.  Light mild roasted malt flavor; some dark chocolate notes.  What really surprised me is the woody cedar aftertaste.  Overall, a great black lager...  Many thanks to BarZigKin for hooking me up with this gem of a beer!
Bottle (in NZ). The best Schwarzbier in the world? Im not sure Id go that far. Ive had some pretty good ones in the Czech republic. But it was very tasty - plenty fof chocolate in this blend.

Black with a big dark brown head. Light roast and hints of coffee and a touch of fruity yeast in the aroma. Faint sweetness followed by a slight burnt coffee flavor. Some light undistinguished fruit flavors in the background. Pretty solid.

Bottle, shared with Tim & Jacob.  Very black, dark tan head.  Nose is roasty & slightly burnt, a little cherry/caramel malt - almost milky.  Flavor is roast & coffee malts, caramel, some cherry.  Nice stuff!

BottlePours a deep mahogany with an aroma of acceptable smoked nut and chocolate.  Flavor follows suit, with more of the latter taking the forefront.  Average mouthfeel.  Drinks like a mass-produced micro trying to be indie, thus the lower rating.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. Much better than I expected. hoppy, not too bitter and not too roasty. very well done beer.

bomber from papago 2/21/10.

very stout pour...opaque black with big puffy orange tinted cappuccino-like head. lacing abound... webby, drippy and otherwise. 

the aroma and flavor are both the same... roasty, ashy, charcoal, chocolate, musty yeast, smoke, earthy moist wood, umami, brown sugar/caramel, a bit sulphuric/doo doo and some light pine. 

it is super creamy, crazy rich, smooth and thick yet really dry (especially on the ashy finish), prickly and insanely drinkable. 

a lager stout... me likey. 7/5/7/5/17/4.1

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in a stemless wine goblet.  As expected, the beer pours a jet black color, with a moderate to large medium tan head.  The nose carries some subtle notes of grassy hops, straw-like malt notes, some dark chocolate notes, and some toasted malt scents.  The palate is carbonated like a kolsch or a pilsner, not off-style or unpleasant, but always a bit of a surprise from a beer with such a lofty SRM.  The flavors seem to resemble an American stout more than the moderately malty flavors of classic Teutonic examples of the style.  Roasted notes up front, a slight straw-like malt flavor, assertive bitterness and charactered hop flavors on the back end.  The finish leaves a lingering bitterness and roasted note in the mouth, but is otherwise clean.  Overall, not unpleasant or poorly conceived, but missing something in the German character malt department that, if traded with a little less bitterness, could elevate the beers enjoyability.

The body is perfectly black with a medium brown sugar colored head. Milk chocolate and roasted peanuts are in the nose. There is also a little bit of fresh ground coffee. The taste has some light cola mixed with milk chocolate. The finish is burnt with coffee and a little hint of prunes. Nice and roasted, this is like a lighter bodied dry stout

Dark black pour with an interesting reddish/tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts with some chocoalte and faint smoke.  Full-bodied, creamy and smooth on the palette.  Smoke comes out a lot more and competes effectively with a nice chocolate flavor.  Slight bitterness lingers with a nice smokey aftertaste.   They used an ofest so I guess it really is a lager, I never would have figured as it is so full-bodied and flavorful.  Very good from Rogue!

Pours darkest brown with a nice-sized tan head that fades to a ring and some swirls.  Aroma is very full and nice with lots of dark chocolate, coffee, and earth.  Flavor is also great and very earthy.  Intense roastiness and coffee along with some dark chocolate and hop bitterness.  This really tastes more like a porter, although I know its a lager.  Smooth and rather hoppy on the palate with medium-full body.  Very good for the style, if you want to call it a schwarzbier.

Whoa. I love Rogue so I picked this up without looking at it closely simply because I hadnt seen it before. This is not at all what I was expecting from a "black lager" but Im very pleasantly surprised. Aroma is heavy on the roasted malt and chocolate with a bit of smokiness. Pours deep black with a huge dark mocha head which was absolutely gorgeous for a few seconds. The head disappeared almost immediately and left no trace at all. Its possible that my glass was to blame but it doesnt feel like a lacer. Full bodied and smooth but very lightly carbonated. Smells, looks, and tastes big but isnt at all and somehow that leaves me wanting, though it shouldnt. Really a nice beer.

Bottle and served in my Duval snifter: Pours near jet black with a creamy head and moderate sticky lace, looks a lot like a Impy Stout in the glass. The aroma has notes of charred black and bittersweet chocolate malts, grassy and herbal hops, an earthy yeast ester, and some molasses like and/or Baltic Porter fruitiness. The taste display a acidic but not really fruity twang, plenty of astrengent black patent malt and finishing hit of mocha powder. The hops display a nice countering bitterness but also seem a tad nondescript, not really PNW resiny nor classic noble character either. The finish is a tad chalky,ashy, and minerally which is to be expected once you know what is in the brew. The mouth feel is tight lively carbonation balanced by the addition heft of the melanoidin, slightly heavier and more aggressive than one normally finds in most Schwarzbiers. Reminds me somewhat of the "Black IPA" I homebrewed but with less bitterness, very similar mouth feel, malt and yeast profiles . A Tour de Force of black malt that not everyone will dig but I know I do.
Pours dark brown with thick head. Lots going on - nutty aroma, malty. Body is mid range with smooth mouthfeel. Roasty malt flavour with some interesting side notes, woodiness, acid. Enjoyable.

Supremo! Poured with a lovely large foamy frothy brown head that subsides quickly and a little lace. Nose is quite roasty malt nutmeats licorice leather tree bark. Color is opaque black with very slight brown highlights. Flavor is like aroma but with a bit of acid. Great body and carbonation. Finish is like flavor and lasts for a while. Easy drinking session beer.
Excellent, albeit seemingly a bit rich for a schwarz - but then has lovely finish.

Bomber. The body is perfectly black with a medium brown sugar colored head. Milk chocolate and roasted peanuts are in the nose. There is also a little bit of fresh ground coffee. The taste has some light cola mixed with milk chocolate. The finish is burnt with coffee and a little hint of prunes. Nice and roasted, this is like a lighter bodied dry stout. It is highly carbonated, but that works for this beer. This is one of the best Rogue brews I have tried.

Black color/ tan head. Big roasty malt, nutty, dark pumpernickel bready aromas. medium body with a smooth mouthfeel.  Earthy, briney, deep roasted malt flavors with dark sourdough bread, cigar tobacco. good.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle purchased at Rozis in Lakewood.  Aroma is a nice light chocolaty malt with a little bit of acidity behind it -like a dark chocolate would have.  Flavor is much the same way.  Like some strong dry coffee, it really tastes dry with a good chocolate malt flavor to it.

Bomber. Very dark brown pour, thick, red/tan head. Big nose of cocoa, hop, malt. Creamy full mouthfeel. Huge taste of chocolate/cocoa, a little bitterness (roasted malt or hop, cant tell the main driver), velvety smooth. Terrific stuff!

Bottle from Capones.  Pours thick black with big 3f tan head.  Nose is choc malt, cacao, hops.  Tastes rich, dark malty, very hoppy, w a huge malt bill that matches the hops well.  Smooth and velvety, and comes off like a very hoppy imperial stout, certainly denser than a schwarz.
Aroma is burnt malts, caramel, and coffee.  I pick up notes od dark chocolate and licorice.  The palate is surprisingly smooth.  The taste is a little too over powering with the burnt malts.

Poured from bottle. Coffee, licorice, and anise/fennel notes on the nose; the color is dark. I mean, REALLY dark. Even the head is dark. The flavor is rich and intense with more coffee and licorice, but surprisingly clean on the finish with a hop kick. Rarely does something this oily finish this clean. Good show.

Bomber courtesy of mitchgt.  Black pour with medium tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, smoke and brown sugar.  Taste is chocolate, coffee, burnt malts and nuts.  The texture is the star here: medium, slick and oily with the perfect spike of carbonation.  Finishes bitter and very dry.  Little skeptical going in as RB has this as the highest rated schwarzbier (hundreds of years of tradition and a newbie is on top...) - but definitely an excellent brew.
Jet black in body with a good size dark tan head. Rich dark chocolate in taste as well as coffee and burnt notes. Quite enjoyable.

Gorgeous black pour with a one finger tan head. Aroma is a lot like a stout, with lots of sweet chocolate, lactic notes of cream, and roasted malt. Flavor is comparable, but with much more roast and an intriguing hop character that conveys the chocolate note from the aroma in a more bitter light. Tons of earthy character in the flavor as well, which really lives up to this beers title. The palate is medium to high in carbonation, but rich and smooth in the mouthfeel, especially as it glides down the throat. Not a style that I know much about, but I must say I really enjoy this. Ive grown sick of many of Rogues offerings, but this is one of their finer efforts.

bottle brought by a friend poured a dark muddy brown color with a dark tan head. aroma has an initial smack of roasted malt, chocolate, underlying hops, and some coffee. mouth feel is a solid medium and has a lactic coating. flavor turns out a lot of roasted malt, peat, rich chocolate, coffee, and again the oddly fit hops. this comes off more like a porter than anything else but the chocolate side is enjoyable.

Pours a very dark brown with probably the darkest head Ive ever seen.  Aroma of chocolate, dark malt, light licorice, coffee and pumpernickel.  Flavor is dark chocolate, fudge, nice roast.  Really rich.  Some malted milk balls, a bit of anise and earth.  I get some smoke hanging out there as well. Really thick and full mouthfeel, quite velvety.  The carbonation really compliments the beer.  Finishes dry with dark chocolate.

22 oz bomber pours like a good motor oil with a massive brown head, quite impressive. The aroma is wonderful smelling of coffee and chocolate. Smooth taste somewhat like a beer malted milk stays on the palate with no aftertaste. I would think this would be a great desert beer. It is not hard to see why this gets such a good rating. I shall have this again.

22 oz. bottle - Pours a dark brown color with a good size tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is a dusty roasted malt, light chocolate, and light herbal hops.  Flavor is bitter black malt, light chocolate, and cola.  Finish is quite dry and kinda thin.  Light to medium body.  A decent beer.

An angry head that looks menacing.  So cool.  It is dark brown and looks like something in a chemical plant vat.  The beer itself is almost black with plenty of red.  This looks like a stout.  The aroma is amazing, too.  Chocolate, black cherries, coffee, mustiness.  It is somehow decadent and decaying at the same time.  First sip brings out anise.  Coffee, smoke, chocolate.  Subtle when compared to those malts are the hops which give a nice yang to the malty ying.  There are massive amounts of ingredients are in here and everything works beautifully.

Pours black with a mid sized tan head that dissipates quickly. I instantly get an aroma of a candy whopper, chocolaty and full of malts. The flavor is full on dark roasted malts. Medium body and carbonation. A bit of smokiness comes through at end with some mild hops. Long dry finish. My first thought is that this would go great with a cigar. I enjoyed the strong flavorful character of this Schwarzbier.
Black,lasting brown head.Burnt brown sugar in both nose and palate.Full bodied with medium burnt bitterness,metallic overtones. Slightly undercarbonated
Pitch black color. Dark brown head. Very earthy, lots chocolate malts,low hops. Full bodied.

Bottle. Jet black hue with a wonderfully fluffy and persistent brown head. Nose is big roast and grains with a clean lager profile, hints of earthy hops. Flavor is a clean grainy malts with a touch of melanoidins, roast, and coffee/cocoa, earthy-grassy hops provide modest bitterness in the middle, finishes clean and slightly sweet. Medium body, smooth carbonation, watery body texture with frothy head. Super-easy to drink lager with an impressive roasty malt profile.

Chatoe Rogue First Growth Dirtoir Black Lager--Independent & Revolution Hops, & Risk Malts--Grow The Revolution--GYO--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  5.63% ABV.  35 IBUs.  15 Plato.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Thick brown pour.  Big dense lacy espresso head.  Opaque jet black ruby edged color.  Delicate burnt chocolate coffee mild hop front.  Mild sweet slightly creamy crusty full roasted smooth coffee "Seamless" black lager body.   Dry mild roasted bitter malt hop end.  Big tight pellicle adds a hint of fruit at end.  Nice.  5/21/2010.  $6.49 Each and almost worth it.

Served from 22 oz bottle into Ommegang Flute.  Pours as black as can be with a two finger tan head.  The aroma is comprised of malts and a slight hint of coffee.  The flavor of this brew has a nice malty flavor with subtle hints of coffee and with a slightly bitter aftertaste when swallowing.  This brew has a light feel on the palate with low carbonation.  There is minimal lacing throughout.  Overall this is a very nice low intensity flavor for a black lager.  It is easy to drink and very enjoyable.  This is a very nice brew by Rogue.  Definitely worth a shot if you have the opportunity.

Bomber. This is one of the best Rogues Ive had. Pours black with a tan head that fades rapidly. Aromas of coffee, smoke, chocolate and yeast. Palate is pleasantly carbonated. Taste is mild and bready at first and then moves into smoke, nuts and chocolate with a bit of a citrus linger.

Tap at BT.  Pours a rich deep black with a tan head- stout like.  Aroma is also stout like with more of a n ale yeastiness, not as clean as lager yeast- earth grass green pine-like hops over big stouty roastiness.  Flavor is also roasty, stout like chocolate malts and more pine and minty PNW hops.  Mostly smooth- just tasted like a hopped up stout though.

Bottle from Perrys in Livermore.  Nose is  thick German yeast/grain combo.  Slightly roasty, slightly bitter in that sloshy German grain way.  Color is glossy jet black.  Flavor is a very pleasing: as even a dunkelweiss as I have experienced.  Balanced, roasty, with a very pleasing wheat quality that is not overly tart or funky.  Good job, Rogue.

Wonderful shwartzbier, sent by Presario.  Pours beautiful black, looks thick, crowned by a small white head.  Very roasty aroma. Slightly malty, roasted coffee-ish, chocolate taste.  Above average mouthfeel.  Satisfying, good moderate maltiness that aids drinkability.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor: Created a thick fluffy pillow of foam that took several minutes to die out while the liquid is opaque and to put it simply, just a dark brown color. In the nose, theres a surface aroma of roasted malts with hints of ground coffee and sour milk. The flavor is a little sour and reminds me of a soy milk or half and half dairy, but there is a faint background of Folgers ground coffee and roast malt that really gives this is an extra kick compared to other black lagers( schwarzbier) being made in the states.

Wow... this beer is black!  Pitch black with a medium-dark brown head thats finely frothy.  Smells malty and uber-roasted.  Coffee flavors apparent, a very stout-like, bitter palate.  Hard to identify as a lager! Sooo good... would be good warmer, too.  Sweet!  Delicious.

If this was what the big guys lager would taste like there would be no need for this lager. Porter or stout like in appearance with a black body and tan head. The aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. The flavor is similar with a bit of smoke in there. Very good.

[Bottle] Pours an opaque black color with a lasting brown head. Good lacing. Aroma of coffee, molasses and lots of dark chocolate. Dry and somewhat grainy throughout. Burnt caramel, heavy chocolate, some peat, bitter coffee grounds. Good palate, with low carbonation levels. Seems a lot more like a Porter than a Schwarzbier (just not enough sweetness here). Still a very good beer in my opinion.

This is the worst beer Ive ever tasted from Rogue.  I get the concept, but dont think it comes together well at all.  I do like the color, but the result of that darkness is a bitter grainy beer.  Aroma is extremely earthy, and any hops are blunted by the thick earthy maltiness.  Flavor has a metallic character followed by bitter coffee.  Wont be trying this one ever again.

Pours thick and dirty.  Color is black hole with wonderful tan brown head that retreats.  Aroma is roasted chocolate malts with a a hint of molasses sweetness.  A somewhat refined coffee flavor with some residual sweetness on the tailend.  Bitterness is largely from the malts.  A bit of nuttiness.  Great brew, but not much difference between this and Sprechers Black Bavarian which is local and cheaper.  Still, excellent showing.

Hmmm...220z bomb - First Growth!  Seems pretty revolutionary to me.  Is this like Earth First! lager we are dealing with here?  Rogue did a great  job here brewing something that taste a lot  "bigger" than it taste.  Plenty of malts and hops to keep everyone happy.  Little yeasty on the finish.  Overall, well done!

Dark  black.  Dark brown, chocolatey head.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt - emphasis on the chocolate but with coffee behind it.  Taste is coffee with chocolate in it, but a bit harsh or bitter from the malt.  Finish is clean and swift.  Enjoyable beer in a big  bottle.

Bottle.  Poured black with a thick chocolate brown head.  Very stout like.  Nose has big notes of coffee and roasted malt.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel and soft carbonation.  Flavor is dark roasted malts and coffee, light grassy hops, a touch of toasted grain, slight ash, and caramel.  Finishes moderately sweet with some chocolate.

I dont know. I didnt dig this one too much. Pours very dark, thin brown head. Nice roasted aroma, but the roasted/burnt flavor seemed unbalanced, mixed with a sour finish. I didnt quite understand this one.

Pours dark brown with an interesting  marbled brown head and a chocolate aroma. There is a chocolate and toffee flavor with a subtle hop bitterness and a dry finish. It all blends nicely into a very tasty brew.
(bottle) black with dark tan head. Aroma of smoked peat and dirt. Flavor is smoked peat, roast malt. Idve believed you if you told me it was a stout.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.
Pours pitch black with a sizeable brown, foamy head.  The nose is robust with notes of black olives, earth, roasted malt, a little smoke, and dark brown sugar.  The palate is earthy with notes of molasses, dirt, and burnt malt.  Lighter on the palate than I was expecting even though it is a black lager.  A cross between a black lager and a stout in terms of consistency.  Light to medium body leading to an earthy and bitter finish.  A very interesting and well brewed beer.  A bit roasty to session in my mind though.

Poured black with thick tan head.
Aroma - burnt wood, dark chocolate and sour vanilla.
Flavor - bitter charred smokey wood mixed with bitter chocolate.
Palate - medium mouthfeel and has oily texture. Finish is dry and very bitter.
Overall - not impressed by this beer. Extremely bitter and not much good flavor.

Pours out a beautiful deep oily black, almost like pouring an imperial stout, a marvellous persistent dense tan head as well.  As far as looks go this is an absolute stunner.  Nice slightly bready, malty nose.  The body is spot on for a black lager, silky, mouthfilling & generous, flavours of roasted cereal, & dark malts, & a long slightly burnt caramel, bitter lingering finish.  This is a tasty beer but for me its real stunning quality is looks & body, the Halle Berry of the beer world

Bottle (shared with Tweety)...  Poured near black with a khaki head.  Lots of malts on this boy, leading to cocoa, burnt oat-like character, coffee with earthy hops to add balance and fruit like tones.

"Jet black in color with a tan head, medium to full bodied, deftly balanced, seamless dark roasted malt flavors with a smooth bitterness, lingering long finish."

Holy crap thats exactly what I was going to say, word for word, honest!

Kidding aside. This is supposed to be a black lager? Makes me laugh even more at the what Heineken thinks of as a dark lager.

Also what a great name "Chatoe Rogue" and with playing up the wine angle "First Growth".

Put Rogue right up there with the best breweries & wineries in the world.

I wouldnt argue.

22oz Bottle. Roasty, salted chocolate aroma, bristling with some hops. Pours very dark black-brown with a creamy tan head. Frothy. Flavors are less exciting than I expect. Some very dark chocolate, roasted hazlenut skin, toffee, and caramel, but not ragingly strong. Palate is dry and enjoyable. Prickly. Decent, maybe not world-winning. A good use of Pacman.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Dark malt aroma with lots of hops added.   
Appearance  Dark brown in color, Clear with a thin head.   
Flavor   Big dark malted lager with tons of added hops this had tons of flavor.   
Palate    Dry malty finish with a Nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall  One kick ass Dark Lager.  I loved this beer.  Good chocolate and coffee like flavors added.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a rich chocolatey brown in color with a cocoa head.  The aroma is lightly roasted coffee and cocoa.  The flavor is rich and malty, notes of chocolate, roasted coffee, a touch of smoke, and light cereal grains.  It is well crafted and smooth to drink.  Very good.

Dark roast, smoke, resin hops. Flavor wise, its like two separate islands--a fairly rich, bitter chocolate stout and a  resiny, slightly edged ipa. The two strains dont clash, which is evidence of the brewers skill, but they dont join, let alone synergize.

first beer in this style i have tried, never seem amything like it in australia. not sure what quite to ecpect considering it was a lager....
the darkness sets you up for an experiance that never happens. although not a bad experiance by anymeans. nice flavour

Celery, coffee and blazing malt dominate the nose, but there is also a distinct background of .....shames me to say....urine, and I could not get rid of it no matter how many times I backed away and started anew. Awesome to look at. Black as midnight with the medium head just as dark. A true dark knight. Burnt bitterness enters the mouth....dominant  burnt char in mid-palate...a whiff of orange citrus near the end followed by bitter hops at the end. The finish tastes like burnt toast. I certainly appreciate the true distinctivness and craftsmanship in the entire makeup of this beer but a little too much charred dominance for me.

Poured out an ultra dark brown that is nothing short of totally black in my glass - slid out of the bottle like oil! Gave way to an inch thick dark brown slightly foamy cap that leaves behind randomness on my glass while retaining more than surface cover the entire time. Well.. half way through 650ml and I only got this far... sure am enjoying this. The aroma is keeping my nose very aware with its chocolatey goodness, ultra dark yet soft roasted malts, maybe earth, something that reminds me of the bottom of an old, dirty leather pouch (hahaha - that sure makes me sound like a teary eyed pillow biter...), hint of an autumn bouquet of flowers, faint citrus and fish. The taste is large, dirty and endless. Massive roast and not overly bitter dark chocolate dominate this beast, ashes, espresso (subdued and acceptable), tang of citrus that I cannot decipher due to the roasted beating my taste buds are receiving, nuts.. maybe almonds? me thinks that is correct. The fruitiness is coming around now but still beaten down... cant place the fruit.. its something red and fleshy with a bit of red apple skin maybe - hard to tell. Hell of a mix - I wonder how many pints I could drink before I could actually sweat the aroma out (kinda like a very long night of Vodka.. or an ungodly serving of garlic). Thick coating is excellent and keeps me coming back for more, placing my mouth in a big ole Lazy Boy, fully reclined. Full bodied, excellent bitterness. This is one big ass satisfying brew that never once let up in pleasing my senses and gave me breath that even my wife can be proud of... for once.

Pours pitch black.  Moderate dark tan head with decent retention and lacing.  Aroma is coffee, roasted malt and a hint of caramel sweetness.  Flavor is noticeably more bitter, essentially replacing the caramel with lots of coffee and burnt toast.  Surprisingly creamy mouthfeel, with some bitterness and alchol in the finish.  OK, but probably not something Id go out of my way to get.

could be the darkest beer Ive ever seen.  darker and a little thicker in texture than other beers in this style, but the flavors are true to the style.  flavors are sweet, but well balanced and not overpowering

22. Black. As in buh-lack. Dark burnt tan head, creamy and dense, comes right up even off a frosty cold pour...and then leaves almost as quickly. Looks like an ad for big fat mash bills while its there, though. Protein rich. Not much lace, though, nor head retention. Roasty, somewhat ashy and a bit smoky nose. Creamy medium body with soft carb, bordering on thick and viscous. Chewy and velvety for sure. Ashy, roasty mid-palate, a little bit of good coffee and maybe a bit of campfire in there. This is every bit as much a schwarzbier as I am an emperor penguin, but it doesnt matter a bit what Rogue or anyone else wants to call it. Its good stuff. At 5%, are you kidding me? This much body and this much flavor, but so clean? I could drink this all day if the price was right.
Bottle.  Black pour with good amount of light brown head.  Cola, dark malt, and chocolate malt aroma.  Flavor is the same, sweet yet bitter from the roast and smooth mouthfeel.

WOW.  Bottle.  Pours an abyss with a coffee foamy tan head.  Deep roasted malts, viney hop tones, very fresh.  Light caramel and a minerals, mild hop resins.  Soft palate very session-able lager with a mild roastiness and fantastic hop tones amongst the malt.  Fantastic.

Pours jet black with a deep mocha head and patchy lace. Ive never seen a schwarzbier this dark. The nose is amazingly deep, rich and lasting, especially for a lager: dark chocolate, cocoa, lightly roasted malt and caramel. Light to medium-bodied and fairly slick with a lingering roasty and slightly bitter finish. Roasty, chocolatey and lightly ashy with a mildly herbal green, hoppy finish. I love it when I gamble on a beer and it pays off. This is easily among the best beers of this style that Ive sampled. Good stuff.

Bottle shared by jbye4334.  Pours opaque with a moderate, brown, frothy head.  Aroma is moderate dark malt, dark chocolate bitterness, smoke, oak, and light fruity esters with some dark fruit (prunes, raisins).  Flavor is moderate dark malt with dark chocolate, prunes, oak, smoke, raisins, and bitter hops.  Full bodied, smooth texture, and high carbonation.

22oz bottle.  Pours a watery looking opaque black with a big tan head.  Smell is very mild, a mix of roast and a touch of lactose.  Taste is very gentle, with a touch of sweet chocolate, giving way to a nice roasty flavor with some bitterness in the finish.

22 oz. bottle; pours dense black with huge chocolate colored head;  appearance overall is that of a rich stout; aromas of husky grains, chocolate, a touch of smoked malt, toasted malts and some sweet grassy hops; ashy, earthy, dry chocolate with roasted nuts and mild raw smokiness; bone dry in the finish and ashy; pretty heavy for a schwarzbier with tangy sweetness and plenty of chocolate again; almost thick texture and mouthfeel; style is kind of tossed out on this one but in the end it is a very tasty brew and my fav from rogue in a long time

An unmistakably lush, DARK chocolate brown brew with light brown, orange hued foam poured from the bottle. I smell chocolate, but my allergies are making it very difficult. It tastes like espresso, creamy, sweet and bitter. But the hops up front open the flavor wonderfully. The finish lingers deeply bittersweet. Yumm!

Bottle; poured a dark brown/black with a big slightly creamy head.  Aroma of froasted malt, caramel, coffee, with some arthiness.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, earth; some earthy like hops in the finish.  Those didnt shine through as much as I thought, but it was still quite a good, and easy drink blacklager.

I am loving this beer. The body is really something special; creamy, as some schwarzbiers, but not overly so, nice carbonation level maintained. Really great roastiness in the flavor - very grainy, almost an earthy ryeness. Bitter chocolate, but not strong. Some good bitterness - 35 IBU aint zero. Super fresh and clean aroma, if you call fresh wet Spring earth and grain fresh. Fits together well. Just a little of an acrid, coffee roast palate. Looks good, tastes good, smells good. Not smooth, hoppier than many. Whew! 

So easily drinkable.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: 22oz bottle. Pours a black body with a finger-width, creamy, very dark brown head that dissipates quickly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is more like a Porter. Lots of dark roasts with some coffee and a moderate chocolate-caramel sweetness. A good amount of nuts along with a light hop. Flavor pushes this even more into the Porter realm. Lots of roast with some coffee and a touch of burnt malt. More of the nuts, moderately sweet caramels and chocolate, and a light hop. Finishes very dry from the roast along with a light, resiny bitterness. Lengthy aftertaste after a medium, very smooth body. Nicely carbonated too. Overall, a very cool schwarz. Definitely pushing the envelope when it comes to style (did I hear Baltic Porter?), but very bold and tasty. I like the smooth, easy drinking body and dry finish a lot. Nicely done.

Pitch black coloured body with a thick dense (three centimetre tall) brown head. Nice look - 95% opacity! Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, a touch of caramel and some nuts - perhaps some mild smoke in there. Lightish-bodied; Mild roasted malt flavour with some caramel, nuts and hardly anything else. Aftertaste shows a mild flavour with a creamy malty flavour with no strong tastes, just some burnt sugars. Overall, a pretty subpar beer, aside from the look, which is really nice. Lacking in flavours, character, complexity and just about everything youd want in a beer. Buy this if you want a stouty looking mild ale, pass it up for a real schwarz though if you want flavour. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 14-March-2010, sampled at home in Washington on 05-April-2010, and I was just happy to see that this wasnt another re-labelled rogue beer they decided to try to con beer drinkers to buy.

Black appearance with a brownish head. Aroma is roasted malt and a little chocolate. Taste is somewhat bittersweet chocolate. A little cloying in the finish, but still very good. I would definitely have it again.

2 inch plus dark brown head of very fine and dense bubbles.  Dark roasted malts, milk chocolate and some mild hazelnut coffee.  Color is a dark brown.  Lots of roasted grains, bitter coffee, some light nuttiness and some raisins.  Bit of cloying sweetness in the back of the throat.  Relatively dry and a bit chalky.  Finishes strong roastyness and lingering coffee.  A pretty good schwartzbier.

pitch black short tan head. looks like an imperial stout. very roasty aroma. smells like an imperial stout, kind-of. lacks the pronounced hoppiness of that style. pretty much straight roasted malt. flavor is extremely roasty, with some lagerish characteristics. the roasted malts just keep on giving and giving.

Pours a black hole and a dark brown head. The aroma is roasty, smokey and fruity. The flavor is very chocolaty with coffee, smoke, soft fruit, ash, and a leafy greeniness that lingers. The palate is huge, very very heavy. Very nice.

Bottle shared by Dogbrick at his Portland beer tasting. Black pour with a medium light brown head. Big time roasty nose with coffee notes and some chocolate. Roasty coffee flavor gives way to chocolate before a smokey coffee finish. A lager? I guess. True to schwarzbier style? Hell no, but could care less. Delicious stout...er um, black lager.

22oz in Chapeau glass.  Black with diminishing brown head.  Smoky, bacony, meaty nose.  Flavor lacks the savory goodness of the aroma; its rather chalky and mineral-forward, and precious little roastiness is to be found.  Finish is very dry, uncannily fleeting and slightly astringent.  This beer is bizarre. Listing should read 130ºL and 75% AA, though I would guess this beers AA to be more like 85%!

The Dan Journal #337.  Tasted 4/1/10.  22oz bomber.  Pitch, opaque and brown.  Webbed ring of khaki head.  Aromas of syrup, toast and dark dried fruits.  Cocoa dust undertone.  Full bodied with a big malt flavor, super bright effervescence and oily slick finish.  Toasty malts that are quickly kicked to the side by the stingingly astringent effervescence and carbonation.  The bitterness really hits you in the grill, but just as quickly subsides.  The lingering finish is rather slick with a bit of the bitterness hanging on.  Nicely done!

Thanks for sharing, bro!  Hey!  A Schwarzbier!  Pours brown with a light-brown head.  Aroma is coffee, cocoa, and roasted malts.  Taste is chocolate, coffee roasts, and some earthy hops.  Tastes like a Schwarzbier should!  Good stuff.

Pours oil-can dark with a chocolaty head that leaves a *really* nice lace down the glass. Doesnt get much better. 

Aroma is chocolaty! At first I thought it was going to be Rogues Mocha Porter, to be honest. Theres some dark fruits in there, but pretty much I smell chocolate.

My first taste, I got hit with a metallic wave, which will ding the palate rating a bit, but it was my first impression. It faded to the background, but stayed present. Other than that, this is a fine Schwarzbier with plenty of smoky flavors.

Overall, its very good and even better than I was expecting from one of my favorite breweries, especially for their first attempt at GYO!

22oz bomber from grape & gourmet. pours surprisingly thick and rich for a "lager" with a jet black color and a thin, dark tan head. aroma is excellent with big notes of buttered, pumpernickel toast, roasted malts, milk chocolate, and mild coffee with hints of top-soil, ash, and grassy hops. flavor is great as well, very earthy, with big, smoked malts, burnt coffee beans, dark, bitter, chocolate, and dry leaves with a hint of sweet caramel. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a lingering, dry, earthy, roasted finish. overall, a damn nice homegrown brew from rogue that can give a few stouts a run for their money even if it is classified as a schwartz.

Pours black with a large, fluffy brown head.  VERY dark.  Aroma is dark rye bread, burned toast, coffee, dirt, leaves, and butter.  Tastes of dark rye, coffee, unsweetened chocolate, dirt, leaves, and a dry grassiness.  Finishes with burned toast, dirt, char, and leaves.  Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  Im very much reminded of Ports Moonlit Session lager because this also seems like a "small beer" made from used imperial stout grain.  Whatever it is, I like it.

Bomber from the Kenwood Liquors in Oak Lawn, IL:  This poured and intensely dark brown body with a creamy brown head.  The aroma had roast barley, cocoa, coffee, and dark caramel.  The flavor has more chocolate with dry roasted coffee beans, cream, and barley.  Nice dry finish, but theres a light hit of sour cream near the end that just seems off.

Really enjoyed this one.
Poured very dark with a brown head.
Malt, chocolate in the aroma.
Very nice on the palate.
Would definitely recommend this beer.

Bomber shared by Chyldking. Pours a dark black color with a foamy chocolate brown head. Nose is malted milk balls and some mill chocolate and raisins. Palate is full, fluffy, leaves a light film on the tongue. Flavor is milk chocolate, some light dark fruits, malted milk balls.

Pours a dark brown color with medium light brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malt, mild chocolate, and light coffee notes.  Even a bit of smoke sneaks by.  Taste is rich chocolate, light roasted coffee, caramel malt, earthy hops.  Very creamy and rich, this reminded me a lot of Dark Helmet from Titletown.

Pours out really black with very small bubbles and 1 finger of tan creamy suds sit on  the top. Lacing clings nicely as you sip the beer, and sticks to the mustache (save for later)
As the suds subside I smell dark chocolate and creamy, burnt malt and a slight smokey aroma. While there is some dark fruit, its the yeast that burns the nose. No alcohol detected here.
Taste is coffee and bitter charred malt. No alcohol here. While this could be a tad bit sweeter and less one-sided , it still has a great flavor.
Mouth feel is clean and refreshing. Rogue Rocked another one.

pours black with a very nice light brown head. aroma is dominated by roasted malt but there is a hint of lager yeast and grassy hops. mouthful is bold and has up front roasted malt and smoothness, transitions to a bitter finish and a lager yeast. i like how much is going on with this beer at a sessionable 5%....

Bottle. Reminded me of an imperial stout. Poured tar black, thick, with a beige head. Big nose of roasted malts, coffee and light chocolate. Very rich flavor. Sweet malts blend nicely with some smoky notes. Medium to big in body with moderate carbonation. Pretty smooth. Lingering Mocha aftertaste. I want to have this beer again.
Black pour with a nice creamy tan head. Aroma is full of roasted malt and coffee. Some bits if bitter chocolate too. Flavor is loaded with coffee and bitter chocolate.  This is really well done.

Bomber from Whole Foods in DC.  Pours a rich deep black with a light brown head, looks like an imperial stout.  Nose is roasty and full of a coffee vibe.  Taste is sweet, roasty and coffeetastic.  Hops are pretty present, overall this is a damn good Schwarz.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2010 I certainly didnt expect this one to taste like a stout, but it does. Aroma is roasted with a faint hint of lager yeast. Flavor is very similar...decent roasted character with only a little lager finish. Not much in the way of hop flavor but there is some lingering hop bitterness. Although a lot of what Rogue brews is over-priced, I like this one and the fact that they are using their own hops/barley.

I really like this.  An impenetrable black oily liquid with a thick cappacino head.  Aromas of fresh-tilled soil, charcoal and bittersweet chocolate.  Char picked up more intensely on tasting.  Sweetness well balanced by light but longlasting bitterness.  Very creamy, luxuriant mouthfeel.  Residual sugars left my lips sticky but brew does not come across as sweet.  Excellent beer.

22oz bottle
This is a nice looking pour: jet black with a long lasting frothy tan head.
Very nice roasty/chocolatey aroma followed by  a medium bodied, roasty malty flavored beer. Very well done.

Bottle shared by superdave -- thanks!  Pours a charcoal black color with a trim beige head.  Smells of toasted malt, barley, dry hops, and faint coffee.  Tastes of each, but with a unwashed earthy (dirtoir indeed) quality that really didnt sit right with me.  Not a fan.

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez moi. Arôme: Odeur de torréfaction avec une pointe de caramel et de chocolat. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dun mince col beige mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café avec une pointe de chocolat et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement torréfié. (Rating #2934)

Did not expect it to look like this, I expected a lager to be clear and light in color.  Deep dark black with thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet chocolate, coffee, and a little sweet bread.   Very crisp flavor, earthy and carbon, light coffee, chocolate. Medium carbonation.  Just a bit of grassy hop bitterness and then some carbon in the finish.  Nice, a little too light.

Bottle. Pours an opaque black with a dense dark brown head. This looks imperial, even though I know it isnt. Aromas of charred malt, dusty chocolate, and coffee. Flavourful burnt malt, coffee and dark chocolate, bitter roasty finish. This really satisfies without clobbering you with high ABV.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
[A] Almost smells like a stout, for being listed as a shwarz. With coffee, chocolate, roast. Smoke comes through very light. Burnt. Back to back with Point 2012. Lager yeast somewhat buried. [A] Very oily, thick, impressive looking black pour. Beautiful frothy brown head. Stout-like in this department. Appealing.
[F] Chocolatey. Rosy. Roasty. Some meaty, fiery, hammy smokiness. Char. Bitter. Alot moreso than the 2012. Earthy. Flavorful. [P] Extremely drinkable. Thin. Nice tingle. Everything comes together well. The hop varieties dont really loan any citrus or extreme bitter. [O] Very very nice beer. Liked this one. Not the most complex brew Ive ever had, but quite excellent. $4 is a steal for this. Just. Totally impressed. Rogue does a good brew, but I dont often repeat. Will have to buy another few while theyre available. Especially with estate-grown ingredients. Homegrown. Yum.

Straight black pour with a lively brown mountainous head. Lacing is sticky and thick. The aroma is bursting with roast and lactic sugars with caramel and biscuit taking up a nice presence in the back. An almost smokey note is presented as the brew warms- perhaps earthen coffee as well. The flavor is predominantly roasty at first, with earthy peat and chocolaty coffee following. The complexity isnt amazing, but the arrangement it. Very nicely done. The palate is medium bodied with a roast-chalk dryish finish, demonstrating low effervescence and excellent quaffability. An amazing example of the style.

Bomber was $6.49 at Pappys Beer Store in Rose Hill, Virginia. Pours jet black and viscous, like a stout. Large tightknit cocoa head is creamy and lasts the journey. Lots of sticky lacing. Aroma is full of dark roasty notes of dark chocolate, roasted almonds, and freshly brewed coffee. Creamy and coating, almost full bodied. The dark roasty notes also dominate the flavor profile. Coffee and bittersweet chocolate are present throughout. Spicy and earthy hop notes emerge in the middle. A nice smoked almond note adds some interest. Quite odd for a schwarzbier. Seems almost like a stout. Enjoyable.

(22 oz. bottle from Rockland Foodservice) Sure seems like a stout...Pours thick and black, inky, smooth and dark with several fingers of rocky mocha head. Rather awesome-looking except for the droopy head. Aroma of molasses, chocolate and coffee. Mouthfeel smooth and thick, lightly milk-shakey and perhaps a touch of chalk in the finish. Flavor of dark chocolate and coffee with very light hint of roasty molasses. Lingering bitter aftertaste. A little cleaner tasting perhaps but flavor profile leans more towards stout than schwarz.
Bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Flavor is coffee and roasted malts, but otherwise kind of boring. Still a very solid beer.

I was expecting something lighter when I bought this. Dont get me wrong. Im perfectly happy with what this turned out to be, its just that basically this seems very much like a very robust stout recipe where they just used lager yeast instead of ale yeast. The body is a little thinner than the murky, pitch black body and brown foam suggested, but this is still a malt monster of a beer.

Bottle at a tasting
Appearance : Little head. Short retention

Aroma : Roasted malt, coffee, caramel. Grain. Quite sweet.

Taste : Roasted malt, grain, some coffee. Finish has a lot of coffee with some roasted grain.

Overall : Not that good. Pretty disappointing actually.

aroma is alternating layers of bakers chocolate with good bittering and softer chocolate notes of the sweeter variety.   appearance is dead opaque with at once well sized muddy head that recedes but lingers as a floating lake amongst the schwarz.  flavor is dark and barely semi-sweet cocoa with cutting bitterness contrasting on the front of the tongue.  moderate palate is fleeting cushion-like but more often moderate.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a frothy brown head that lasts a little while. Aroma has cocoa, salty licorice, roasted (almost burnt) malt, leather, coffee and caramel notes. Flavour is similar though not as complex with cocoa, licorice and roasted malt standing out. Smooth, light mouthfeel with fairly high carbonation and a lingering roasty, bitter finish. Very nice schwarz, quite intense roastiness but well balanced, tasty and easy to drink.

Sampled on 2/5/2010. This schwartzbeir pours an eclipse black color from a 22oz bottle. Medium to large sized tan foamy head, with nice retention and good lacing. The aroma is roasty and chocolate with a touch of floral hops. A medium to full bodied schwartzbeir. The malts are roasty, chocolate and coffee. The hops are floral and earthy. Very creamy and full bodied for a schwarzbier. Good carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
A black beer with a small head-this thing is thick black-looks like a stout. The aroma is roasted. The taste is roasted with some coffee and chocolate. Tastes like a stout also. Pretty good.

Bottle: Pours pitch black with a striking dark brown head. The nose is very roasty with lots of cocoa and crusty notes. The flavor is dry and roasty with a semi-sweet chocolate and coffee note in the tail. Very big body for such a light beer with lots of explosive roasty notes all over the place. Great schwarz!

A eich tan head on top a very dark ale the carbonation is medium looking aroma coffee vanilla liccorice flavour dry coffee beans mocha like liccorice vanilla chocolate bright tasting finish malt chocolate coffee good lasting malt tastes and mild bitter

Bottle. Looks like a Bells Stout! Thick coffee head on black beer. Rich dark malt, coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Nutty bitter chocolate flavour. Tasty thick and black. Edgy hops and dusty malt chocolate finish. I should replace my morning coffee with this!

My Bottom Line:
Roasted malts and their coffee allusions delve into caramel and chocolate sweetness for a big and bold cousin to the Schwarzbier style.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the blackness.
-This is way too bulky for it to be a classic representation of a Schwarzbier, but I cannot say the mouthfeel is not pleasant.
-Some hop resins create bitterness alongside that of the roasted malts.
-Minty edges are also found in the finish.

Bottle.
An interesting effort from Rogue.  Black pour with a thin head.  Dark roasted malt and coffee with a bit of a dirty hop profile.  Good, and definitely different.

Bottle from the Eastchase Majestic.  Black pour with a dark brown head.  Aroma is lots of bitter cocoa, vanilla, roasted malts, caramel, and a little coffee.  Taste is coffee, chocolate, bitter, and earthy.

I wasnt expecting such a rich and complex beer.  Was thinking it would be a plain dark lager session beer.  Toffee and caramel aroma.  Roasty smoky aroma too.  Smoke lingers on the tongue nicely.  A little bit of sweetness too
Super black with really dark cocoa head. No aroma. Some roasted malt flavor but quickly falls to the thinness of the beer. Needs a bit mire body.

I was a bit shocked when I started pouring this. I have been drinking a lot of WR stout from a party pig and this black lager reminds me of it a lot. Strong roasted black malts in aroma, quite sweet smelling, lots of coffee too but it isnt the predominant smell. Pours with a CRAZY INSANE head, its a good thing I have a giant glass for the bigger bottles (usually 750 mls) and this filled the whole cup to the top with head. Very tight bubbles, fantastic lacing, black, dark and BLACK! Flavour starts with the coffee and comes into the sweet malts. The malts linger a long time, but it is a fairly thinnish brew, you can just taste a bit of the 6.2% (I find it quite odd that they dont put that on the bottle themselves, I all-grain brew and dont know what all the info on there really refers too but ABV is quite usefull) As the beer goes down.... there is a more lingering alcohol taste. Its a bit high for the malt and hops to really cover up for the long run. A great black lager, just a bit too high % that you can taste and smell.

Bomber courtesy of SuperDave  thanks Dave!  Pours black with a 2 finger mocha head.  The nose is burnt rubber and roasted malt.  The taste is burnt malt, smoke, pine and bitter coffee.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Interesting beer.  Not great, but not too bad either.  Thanks again Dave.

Royal black, opaque in fact, with dark brown head.  Nose is a whollop of lovely roasted malts.  On the palate this beer comes across more like a true dark & bittersweet chocolate than any other in recent memory.  Loads of dark chocolate and roasted malt.  Finish isnt too sweet, yet plenty of roasty bitter dark chocolate to take away with you.
A very pleasant beer - a rich flavor and dark tan head like a porter, but a light body (although not as light as I think of "dark lager"). Notes of coffee and chocolate.

Bottle, thanks to Macadem for the share. Pours big black and viscous, with a thin off-white head, spotty lacing. Nose is smoke, roast barley, bitter chocolate, some fudgey character, vanilla, an odd tree-bark like note that I am unable to pin down... Flavor shows the lagering, as the nose was quite stout-like, clean, round, and rather smoky and bitter, chocolate notes seem ill applied atop a bitter base. Some odd hybrid between Schwarzbier and Baltic Porter, but not as good as either.

Bottle. Near black with a tan/brown head. Roasty coffee like malty aroma with some light smoky/tobacco notes and a hoppy hint. The flavor has hard roasted malts, a light smoky note, some earthy hoppy bitterness, and a light dry dark chocolate sweetness. Really good.

650ml brown bottle. Black velvetly looking pour, holds a rather large and frothy  column of light brown head. Some creamy lacing. Chocolate malt nose, some coffee. Roasty flavour, coffee beans, stoney, earthy and mineral notes. Dry finish, with roast malt lingering deep in the throat and some leafy hop notes. Soft body, restrained tight beads of carbonation. Clean,straightforward  and exactly what I was expecting, a soft and flavourful Schwarzbier that invites quaffing.

Everything about this beer reminds me more of a stout than a lager. Pours Black with a brown frothy head, good lacing. It has a roasted malt/chocolate aroma to it. Tastes like the latter as well with full bodied bitter finsh.
Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Roasty aroma. Roast and chocolate flavor with citrus hops. Medium bodied. Chocolate, citrus, and roast linger.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2010 Bottle. Heavy toasted and coffee ground aromas for the malt, moderate resin and earth for the hops and yeast with a big hint of tar in the background. Head is small, creamy with some big bubbles, brown with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts and ends lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium to full, watery with a soft carbonation and a very dry finish. The unique bitterness right up front really made me take notice of this well made Shwarzbier.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2010 Bottle Pitch black lager with a small, creamy, brown head. Great retention. The aroma is a foreboding blend of charcoal, dark chocolate and espresso sludge with peripheral notes of vanilla and cola.  Full-bodied with lively carbonation. The flavor is well-balanced, burnt and acrid with lots of espresso. Crisp, singed, dry finish. Kudos to glennmastrange for sharing the bottle!

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 For a "black lager" this is quite stout or porter-like with its black body and plush deep, roasty brown head. The nose is replete with black patent and singes of charcoal. The body is sooty, chalky black patent. Like what your beer would tase like if it was with you in the coal mines all day. Touches of burn chocolate, but thick with charcoal and burnt paper/ash finish. Somewhat novel in style.  Re-rated: 1-8-11: Roasty anisey/black licorice. Thick, oil can, stewy cauldron of roastiness.

Courtesy of jcwattsrugger. Initially it seemed to pour inky black but in the glass appeared merely dark with mahogany edges and thin tan head. The aroma has notes of a modest level of smokiness, some roasted malts, a light amount of burnt malts, black licorice and mild spiciness. The taste is smooth bringing up an initial pulse of smoked malts and then moving more and more toward roasted malts, a thin layer of burnt malts and some sweet black licorice. It ends even and as smooth as it started with lingering burnt malts heading off into the after taste.
Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer.  The look is black in color, dark, big tan head.  The smell is malts, coffee, roasty, and slight chocolate.  Thin feel.  The taste is the same as the smell.

22oz bottle @Tampa Wkly Gathering @BT courtesy Ibrew2or3-pours a dissipating brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-roasty/chocolate.  Taste is dark malt-roasty/chocolate/ashy, earthy hops.  Medium body.
